Award.AwardTitle: Microaggressions in Engineering Student Teams: Effects on Learning, Performance, and Persistence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Because engineering is cast as a masculine field, women engineering students can experience subtle yet pervasive stereotypic messages in their learning environments that can negatively influence their experiences. This early stage research project will identify specific behavioral manifestations of gender stereotypes--microaggressions--and their cumulative effect on learning, performance, and persistence in introductory engineering course teamwork. Such microaggressions may cause the climate of the team to become less welcoming to women. The proposed research unites two areas of strong research interest (social science research on gender stereotypes and engineering education on teamwork and climate) to advance understanding of women's underrepresentation in engineering as compared to men.

The goal of the project is to identify and reliably measure microaggressions in both lab-based and classroom-based engineering student project teams. The research will test whether exposure to microaggressions increases perceived stereotype threat and diminishes a sense of belonging in engineering for women compared to men, leading to a gender gap favoring men in the important engineering outcomes of learning, performance, and persistence. The research program builds on prior NSF-funded work of the investigators and includes five research activities. The goal of Study One is to identify the specific types of microaggressions (e.g., ignoring women's contributions or assigning women to less important tasks) occurring in videotaped laboratory-based engineering teams. Researchers will develop a reliable microaggressions assessment procedure, and will analyze effects on engineering outcomes (learning, performance, and persistence). In Study Two, the lab-based data will be supplemented with qualitative data reported by students who previously participated in an engineering student group project, via student focus groups. Study Three will examine the influence of microaggressions occurring in class-based teams on engineering outcomes over time. Introductory engineering student teams will be tracked and observed at three time points in one semester to measure microaggressions and their influence on academic and psychological outcomes. In studies Four and Five engineering students (both women and men) will be randomly assigned to view one of two videos showing student teams in which microaggressions are present or absent in team interactions. The researchers will analyze the effects of the different videos on the students knowledge of the content of the video and their persistence in solving problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this project were to rigorously identify specific behavioral manifestations of microaggressions in the engineering student context, and to examine the effects of microaggressions on learning, performance, and persistence in introductory engineering course teamwork.  This work can inform the development of improved instructional resources and faculty training materials with the goal of improving academic outcomes for all students.

 

This was accomplished through a series of studies including focus group and archival data analysis to develop a behavioral coding scheme, as well as two supplementary survey studies and two laboratory studies.

 

A behavioral coding rubric was developed and tested to document microaggressions as judged by trained observers.  Key findings of the analysis of archived videos of student teams working on 90-minute team projects in the laboratory setting revealed that the most prevalent form of microaggression in undergraduate engineering teams is the assumption of inferiority, which was observed to happen more often to women than men.  Being observed to be targeted by this microaggression was associated with negative perceptions of one’s performance in the team, and a lower sense of belonging on the team. These associations emerged for both male and female students – but women were significantly more likely than men to be targeted by this microaggression.

 

An online survey exploring self-reported experiences of microaggressions among undergraduates at four-year institutions showed that among Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) students, women reported being targeted by microaggressions more than men, and that women report witnessing other women being targeted by microaggressions more than men. Of importance, we tested whether only women who are sensitive to gender bias are harmed by experiencing microaggressions. We found that this was not the case. Among STEM women, we found that outcomes were diminished among those who were sensitive to gender bias compared to those who were not; however, experiencing microaggressions was found to diminish outcomes even among those who were not sensitive to gender bias. This suggests that women’s outcomes may be diminished regardless of their sensitivity to gender bias to the extent they experience microaggressions in STEM environments.

 

The first laboratory study was an observational study to document the occurrence and effects of microaggressions on real engineering student teams over the course of a semester. Engineering student group project teams held 3 successive meetings in our laboratory.  Their team interactions were videorecorded, and they completed questionnaires. For all participants, self-reported experiences with microaggressions while working on the group project were negatively correlated with engineering self-efficacy, expectations for engineering success, and feelings of inclusion in the team, and were positively correlated with gender stereotype threat and feelings of burnout on the team. The microaggression coding rubric was applied to their videorecorded interactions to assess observed microaggressions.  Results showed that women observed by independent judges to be highly targeted by microaggressions reported lower engineering identification than those less targeted. This pattern did not emerge among men, and did not emerge regarding self-reported microaggressions. These results show that STEM women’s identification with their field was diminished when they were observed to be targeted by microaggressions, even when they themselves did not label those experiences as microaggressions. This provides suggestive evidence that using objective assessments of microaggressions (an independent judge’s observations) can reveal associations between microaggressions and women’s STEM outcomes that are not found using self-reported microaggressions.

 

The second laboratory study was designed to test the effects of viewing microaggressions emerging in an engineering team that participants expected to later join. Undergraduate STEM majors were told they would join a mixed-gender group to complete an engineering design task, a situation that can induce stereotype threat for female students.  Participants first viewed a video showing a previous meeting of their future team, who were actually actors enacting scripted microaggressions or neutral interactions.  Participants then completed a spatial ability test, before being told that the experiment would end without them actually doing the design task with the team, after which participants were fully debriefed. 

 

Preliminary results revealed that for women who saw neutral team interactions, spatial ability test scores were lower for women who were higher in gender identification.  This is consistent with work showing that women more strongly identified with gender are more vulnerable to stereotype threat. For women who saw their future team engage in microaggressions, test performance was low regardless of gender identification. This suggests that seeing microaggressions leads even low gender identified women to score poorly on the test. Unlike women, men’s test scores were unaffected by gender identification and experimental condition.

 

In sum, this project showed that microaggressions in an engineering context can be documented through independent observation, and that these observed microaggressions predict significant outcomes for women.  We also demonstrated that simply observing microaggressions targeting other women in one’s environment can affect women’s outcomes in the engineering context.
